Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Affordable Three-dimensional Microscopic Imaging
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project will provide affordable, three-dimensional (3D) microscopic imaging through the use of an electronically-controlled, focusing element. Scientists desire to observe biological phenomena in intact, living cells or animals that occur on fast time scales. Recent advances in fluorescent markers have significantly improved tracking of drug delivery and observation of dynamic events in cell membranes. However, laboratories often need expensive scanning microscopes, such as confocal or two-photon, with 3D fluorescent imaging capability to observe such events. The proposed technology will increase accessibility of 3D, high-resolution imaging, thereby enabling advancements in science. It will also improve the speed of image acquisition, reduce photobleaching and photodamage of specimens, extend longitudinal studies capabilities, and reduce agitation and damage of sensitive samples. It is expected to lead to new discoveries with regard to biological phenomena, physical phenomena, and novel fluorescent imaging modalities. The value of the immediate addressable market is $50 million. The technology also promises to benefit 3D imaging systems for manufacturing or machine vision, miniaturized optical disk pick-ups, confocal and two-photon microscopes, optical coherence tomography, and endoscopic imaging systems by providing high speed and agile focus control.

The intellectual merit of this project centers on the demonstration of the feasibility of a novel 3D, high-resolution imaging technology. The project includes development of microelectromechanical mirrors and a novel optomechanical design. Gross electronic focus control capability has only recently become available. As such, standard optical design practices to best utilize these elements do not exist. The goals of this project are three fold: 1) to advance optical design methods for varifocus elements, 2) to develop a novel optomechanical design, and 3) to further microelectromechanical systems (MEMS) mirror technology. The research and development to be undertaken in Phase I will determine feasibility of the optomechanical design and of the MEMS mirror performance to meet 3D biological imaging needs at a cost less than one quarter of currently available technology. Technical results will include analysis of the new optomechanical design and characterization of the MEMS mirrors.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Scientists desire to observe microscopic biological phenomena that occur on fast time scales in living cells and animals. Scanning laser microscopes, at a price-point of several hundreds of thousands of dollars, currently acquire x-y-z stacks for later processing. This time-consuming, point-by-point imaging can lead to excess exposure and irrevocable damage in fluorescent particles and fails to capture fast events. This project successfully demonstrated feasibility for micro-electro-mechanical systems (MEMS) focusing mirrors to enable fast 3D microscopy at an affordable price to academic researchers. Agile Focus Designs™ MEMS mirrors perform variable focusing without translation of optical lenses or the sample. The technology allows real-time observation of dynamic events, increases throughput, prevents agitation/destruction of samples, and reduces photodamage of fluorescent particles during time-lapse experiments. The main objectives to fabricate novel MEMS mirrors designed for robust manufacturing, to characterize these mirrors, and develop an optical design have been met and expectations were exceeded.

Significant advances in microfabrication methods and optical design methods for varifocus elements have been made. Gross electronic focus control capability has only recently become available. As such, this project contributes toward standard optical design practices to best utilize varifocus elements, since traditional optical analyses assume fixed focal length lenses or mirrors.

Affordable 3D microscopic imaging will significantly broaden the range of scientists who can observe microscopic dynamic events by offering a price point that is one tenth of more complex microscopes. The fast (tenfold faster than competing technologies) and high numerical aperture 3D imaging capability is expected to lead to new discoveries regarding biological phenomena and novel fluorescent imaging modalities. The technology also promises to benefit 3D imaging systems for manufacturing or machine vision, confocal and two-photon microscopes, optical coherence tomography, and endoscopic imaging systems. While MEMS are ubiquitous in mobile platforms and the automotive industry for motion sensing, they have not yet permeated other markets or imaging systems to the same extent. With recent advances in fabrication and performance of optical MEMS devices, bringing this type of technology to other platforms can spark greater commercialization of MEMS technology in non-traditional areas.
